column2: Low Saxon: Flensborg; North Frisian: Flansborj; South Jutlandic: Flensborre) is an independent town (kreisfreie Stadt) in the north of the German state of Schleswig-Holstein. Flensburg is the centre of the region of Southern Schleswig. After Kiel and Lübeck
column3: it is the third largest town in Schleswig-Holstein.

column2: Flensburg was the seat of the last government of Nazi Germany
column3: the so-called Flensburg government led by Karl Dönitz
column4: which was in power from 1 May
column5: the announcement of Hitler's death
column6: for one week
column7: until German armies surrendered and the town was occupied by Allied troops. The regime was officially dissolved on 23 May.

column1: The nearest larger towns are Kiel (86 kilometres (53 miles) south) and Odense in Denmark (92 km (57 mi) northeast).
Flensburg's city centre lies about 7 km (4 mi) from the Danish border.

Flensburg is situated in the very north of the German state Schleswig-Holstein
column2: on the German-Danish border. After Westerland on the island of Sylt it is Germany's northernmost town. Flensburg lies at the innermost tip of the Flensburg Firth
column3: an inlet of the Baltic Sea. Flensburg's eastern shore is part of the Anglia peninsula.

column1: The town of Flensburg is divided into 13 communities

Flensburg was founded at the latest by 1200 at the innermost end of the Flensburg Firth by Danish settlers
column2: who were soon joined by German merchants. In 1284
column3: its town rights were confirmed and the town quickly rose to become one of the most important in the Duchy of Schleswig. Unlike Holstein
column4: however
column5: Schleswig did not belong to the German Holy Roman Empire. Therefore
column6: Flensburg was not a member of the Hanseatic League
column7: but it did maintain contacts with this important trading network.

column1: Historians presume that there were several reasons for choosing this spot for settlement:
Trade route between Holstein and North Jutland (namely the Hærvejen or Ochsenweg
column2: a name for a series of roads between hamburg
column3: Schleswig-Holstein and Jutland
column4: possibly dating from the Bronze Age)

column1: The Angelnway: Trade route between North Frisia and Angeln

column3: were what brought about the blossoming of the town's trade in the Middle Ages. They were sent inland and to almost every European country.

column2: Queen Margaret I of Denmark died of the Plague aboard a ship in Flensburg Harbour.

column1: From time to time plagues such as bubonic plague
column2: caused mainly by rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis
column3: a parasite found on brown rats)
column4: "red" dysentery and other scourges killed a great deal of Flensburg's population. Lepers were strictly isolated
column5: namely at the St.-Jürgen-Hospital (Helligåndshospital
column6: built before 1290)
column7: which lay far outside the town's gates
column8: where the St. Jürgen Church is nowadays. About 1500
column9: syphilis also appeared. The church hospital "Zum Heiligen Geist" ("To the Holy Ghost") stood in Große Straße

column1: A Flensburger's everyday life was very hard
column2: and the old roads and paths were bad. The main streets were neither paved nor lit at night. When the streets became really bad
column3: the citizens had to make the dung-filled streets passable with wooden pathways. Only the few upper-class houses had windows. In 1485
column4: a great fire struck Flensburg. Storm tides also beset the town occasionally. Every household in the town kept livestock in the house and the yard. Townsfolk furthermore had their own cowherds and a swineherd.

column1: After the fall of the Hanseatic League in the 16th century
column2: Flensburg was said to be one of the most important trading towns in the Scandinavian area. Flensburg merchants were active as far away as the Mediterranean
column3: Greenland and the Caribbean. The most important commodities
column4: after herring
column5: were sugar and whale oil
column6: the latter from whaling off Greenland. However
column7: the Thirty Years' War put an end to this boom time. The town was becoming Protestant and thereby ever more German culturally and linguistically
column8: while the neighbouring countryside remained decidedly Danish.

column3: Flensburg had yet another boom. Cane sugar was imported from the Danish West Indies (now the US Virgin Islands) and refined in Flensburg. Only in the 19th century
column4: as a result of industrialization
column5: was the town at last outstripped by the competition from cities such as Copenhagen and Hamburg.

column1: The rum blended in Flensburg then became a secondary industry in West Indian trade
column2: as of 1864 no longer with the Danish West Indies
column3: but with Jamaica
column4: then ruled by the British. It was imported from there
column5: blended
column6: and sold all over Europe. There is nowadays only one active rum distillery in Flensburg

column3: after Copenhagen
column4: the second biggest port in the Kingdom of Denmark
column5: but it passed to the Kingdom of Prussia after the Second Schleswig War in 1864. The Battle of Flensburg was on February 6
column6: 1864: near the city a small Hungarian mounted regiment chased a Danish infantry and Dragoon regiment. There is still a considerable Danish community in the town today. Some estimates put the percentage of Flensburgers who belong to it as high as 25%; other estimates put that percentage much lower. The SSW political party representing the minority usually gains 20–25% of the votes in local elections
column7: but by no means are all of its voters Danes. Before 1864
column8: more than 50% belonged to what is now the minority
column9: witnessed even today by the great number of Danish surnames in the Flensburg telephone directory (Asmussen
column14: etc.). The upper classes and the learned at that time
column18: the German language has prevailed in the town.

column2: Flensburg became an independent city (kreisfreie Stadt) within the Province of Schleswig-Holstein
column3: and at the same time still kept its status as seat of the Flensburg district. In 1920
column4: the League of Nations decided that the matter of the German-Danish border would be settled by a vote. As a result of the plebiscite
column5: and the way the voting zones were laid out
column6: some of Flensburg's northern neighbourhoods were ceded to Denmark
column7: whereas Flensburg as a whole voted with a great majority to stay in Germany.

column1: In return for this great pro-German majority
column2: the town of Flensburg was given a large hall
column3: the "Deutsches Haus"
column4: which was endowed by the government as "thanks for German loyalty".

column2: the town was left almost unscathed by the air raids that devastated other German cities. However
column4: 20 children died when their nursery school was bombed
column5: and shortly after the war ended
column6: an explosion at a local munitions storage site claimed many victims.

column3: who was briefly President (Reichspräsident) of Nazi Germany once Adolf Hitler had appointed him his successor and then killed himself
column4: fled to Flensburg with what was left of his government where they were taken prisoner by British troops and deposed in Mürwik at the Navy School in Mürwik (German: Marineschule Mürwik). Flensburg was thereby
column5: for a few weeks

column1: In the years after the Second World War
column3: particularly in Flensburg
column4: a strong pro-Danish movement connected with the idea of the "Eider Politics". Its goal was for the town and all or most of Schleswig
column5: the whole area north of the Eider River
column6: to be united with Denmark. After 1945
column7: Flensburg's town council was for years dominated by Danish parties
column8: and the town had a Danish mayor.

column1: The town profited from the planned location of military installations. Since the German Reunification
column2: the number of soldiers has dropped to about 8
column3: 000. Since Denmark's entry into the European Economic Community (now the European Union)
column4: border trade has played an important role in Flensburg's economic life. Some Danish businesses
column5: such as Danfoss
column6: have set up shop just south of the border for tax reasons.

column2: the Flensburg district was expanded to include the municipalities in the Amt of Medelby
column3: formerly in the Südtondern district
column4: and in 1974 it was united with the Schleswig district to form the district of Schleswig-Flensburg
column5: whose district seat was the town of Schleswig. Flensburg thereby lost its function as a district seat
column6: but it remained an independent (district-free) town.

column1: The Danish minority in Flensburg and the surrounding towns run their own schools
column2: libraries and Lutheran churches from which the German majority is not excluded. The co-existence of these two groups is considered a sound and healthy symbiosis.  There is a form of mixed Danish–German used on the ferries
column3: Petuh.

column1: There is also a Danish Consulate-General in Flensburg.In Denmark
column2: Flensburg seems to be mainly known for its "border shops" where
column3: among other things
column4: spirits
column5: beer and candy can be purchased at cheaper prices than in Denmark. The prices are lower because the value-added tax is lower and excise taxes are either lower (e.g. on alcohol) or do not exist (on e.g. sugar). Currently the border shops are able to sell canned beer to persons resident in Scandinavia without paying deposits as long as the beverage is not consumed in Germany.

column1: The town council was led for centuries by two mayors
column2: one for the north town (St. Marien) and the other for the south town (St. Nikolai and St. Johannis). The council members and the mayors were chosen by the council itself
column3: that is
column4: retiring officials had their successors named by the remaining councillors in such a way that both halves of the town had as many members. These councillors usually bore the title "Senator".

column1: This "town government" lasted until 1742 when the "northern mayor" was made the "directing mayor" by the Danish King. From this position came what was later known as the First Mayor. The second mayor simply bore the title "mayor" ("Bürgermeister"). After the town had been ceded to Prussia
column2: the mayors were elected by the townsfolk as of 1870
column3: and the First Mayor was given the title Oberbürgermeister
column4: still the usual title in German towns and cities. During the Third Reich
column5: the town head was appointed by those who held power locally at the time.

column3: a twofold leadership based on a British model was introduced. Heading the town stood foremost the Oberbürgermeister
column4: who was chosen by the town council and whose job was as chairman of council and the municipality. Next to him was an Oberstadtdirektor ("Higher Town Director") who was leader of administration. In 1950
column5: when Schleswig-Holstein brought its new laws for municipalities into force
column6: the title Oberbürgermeister was transferred (once again) to this latter official. At first
column8: he was chosen by the council. Since that time
column9: the former official has been called the Stadtpräsident ("Town President")
column10: and is likewise chosen by the council after each municipal election. However
column12: the Oberbürgermeister has been chosen directly by the voters as once before.

column1: The first directly elected Oberbürgermeister Hermann Stell died on 4 May 2004 of a stroke. On 14 November of the same year
column2: the independent candidate suggested by the CDU Klaus Tscheuschner was elected to replace Stell with 59% of the vote. In the municipal election in 2003
column3: Hans Hermann Laturnus was elected Stadtpräsident.

column2: the local list WiF (Wir in Flensburg) was elected largest group in the Council Assembly of Flensburg
column3: with its 10 city councillors out of 43
column4: closely followed by the South Schleswig Voter Federation (Südschleswigscher Wählerverband) (9 councillors) and the CDU (9 councillors). Also elected was the SPD (seven councillors)
column5: the Greens (3 councillors)
column6: the Left (3 councillors) and the FDP (2 councillors). Nevertheless
column7: since the WiF-group was divided into two different caucuses
column8: the SSW-group has been the largest group in the Council Assembly. The current City President is Dr. Christian Dewanger (WiF).In the mayoral election of 2010
column9: Simon Faber (SSW) was elected Lord Mayor of the town in a run-off election with 54
column10: 8% of the vote. He is the first person from the Danish Minority to occupy this office since the end of World War II.

column1: Flensburg's coat of arms shows in gold above blue and silver waves rising to the left a six-sided red tower with a blue pointed roof breaking out of which
column2: one above the other are the two lions of Schleswig and Denmark; above is a red shield with the silver Holsatian nettle leaf on it. The town's flag is blue
column3: overlaid with the coat of arms in colour.

thus expressing the town's unity with these two historic lands. The tower recalls Flensburg's old town rights and the old castle that was the town's namesake (Burg means "castle" in German). The waves refer to the town's position on the Flensburg Fjord.

column1: The coat of arms was granted the town by King Wilhelm II of Prussia in 1901
column3: newly approved form on 19 January 1937 by Schleswig-Holstein's High President (Oberpräsident)

column1: The town has a well established Combined Heat and Power and District Heating scheme which was installed between 1970 and 1980. It is owned by the town.
West of Flensburg runs the A 7 Autobahn
column2: leading north to the Danish border
column3: whence it continues as European route E45. Furthermore
column4: Federal Highways (Bundesstraßen) B 200 and B 199 pass through the municipal area.

column1: Also west of the town lies the Flensburg-Schäferhaus airport.

Local transport is provided by several buslines such as "Aktiv Bus GmbH" and "Allgemeinen Flensburger Autobus Gesellschaft" (AFAG) along with others. They all operate within an integrated fare system within the Flensburg transport community (Verkehrsgemeinschaft Flensburg). They also all subscribe to the Schleswig-Holstein tariff system whereby anyone travelling from anywhere in Schleswig-Holstein or Hamburg may use Flensburg buses free to connect with their final destinations. It works both ways
column3: and a rider boarding any bus in Flensburg need only name his destination anywhere in Schleswig-Holstein or Hamburg
column4: pay his fare
column5: and travel all the way to that destination on the one ticket.

column1: The current Flensburg station was opened in 1927 south of the Old Town. From there
column2: trains run on the main line to Neumünster and on to Hamburg and to Fredericia
column3: among them some InterCity connections as well as trains serving the line running to Eckernförde and Kiel. Another stop for regional trains to Neumünster is to be found in Flensburg-Weiche. The stretch of line to Niebüll has been out of service since 1981
column4: efforts to open it again notwithstanding. The secondary line to Husum and the lesser lines to Kappeln and Satrup no longer exist. Even the tramway
column5: which opened in 1881 to horse-drawn trams
column6: was electrified in 1906 and at one point ran four lines was replaced with buses in 1973.

column1: Flensburg has a well preserved Old Town with many things to see from centuries gone by. Characteristic is the row along the waterfront. Three of the four old town cores are found along this north-south axis. The building boom in Imperial times led to a partial rebuilding of the Old Town
column3: and rather leading to notable expansion of the town. Virtually unscathed in the Second World War
column4: Flensburg
column5: like other places in Germany
column6: adopted a policy of getting rid of old buildings and building anew in the style of the times. This trend was limited in Flensburg by a lack of money
column7: but before the policy was finally stopped in the late 1970s
column8: countless old buildings had been demolished in the north and east Old Town to be replaced by newer structures. Despite great losses
column9: Flensburg still comes across as having a compact
column10: well preserved Old Town in the valley with good additions to what was built in the founders' time on the surrounding heights.
